The Situationin Germany.* e e(previous reference:Cabinet 29(32),Conclusion 2).The DisarmamentConference.(previous reference;Cabinet 2(33),Conclusion 1).1. . The Secretary of State for Foreign affairs warned the Cabinet that the international situation in Europe was deteriorating very fast.He hoped to be in a position to circulate amemorandum on the subject to the Cabinet within48 hours.In Germany the immediate situation was particularly critical.He had news from Geneva that there was a real danger that the Disarmament Conference mightbreak down within the next ten days or a fortnight,and he was expecting proposals from the Parlia-mentary Under Secretary at Geneva with a view toaverting a breakdown. In this connection theSecretary of State invited particular attentionto the League of Nations telegram from Geneva,No. 141.The Cabinet agreed -That the Searetary of State forForeign Affairs should, if hethought a special meeting of theCabinet desirable, discuss thematter with the Prime Minister.He was asked also to give warning to the Secretary to the Cabinetto whom Ministers could apply asto the probability of an emergencymeeting.The Situation inEurope. THE AGRICULTURAL 2. The Cabinet had before them once more the marketing BILL.Memorandum by the Minister of Agriculture and(previous reference: Fisheries (CP. 58(33)) covering the draft Agricul-Cabinet LO(33), Con- tural Marketing Bill, consideration of which, afterelusion 6).a preliminary discussion at the Meeting mentionedin the margin, had been postponed.The Minister of Agriculture and fisheries said that he and the President of the Board of trade had been able to reach agreement on the Bill, on theunderstanding that Sub-section (b) of Clause 1 was withdrawn, and words substituted to the effect thatan Order might be granted to enable the Board ofTrade to make an Order regulating the importation ofany agricultural product,in regard to which theMinister of Agriculture was satisfied that an agricultural marketing scheme was in course of preparation. This alteration would remove the very wide latitude given under the early sub-section (b)"to meet an emergency affecting the economic stability of any branch of the /agricultural/industry".The discussion on this Bill extended over aconsiderable portion of the field of industrial activity.The Cabinet agreed:-(a) That the Bill should be referredto the Committee of Home Affairs;(b) That if any question of principle on which there was a difference ofopininn arose at the Committee ofHome Affairs, the question should bebrought back to the Cabinet, but thatotherwise the Minister of Agricultureand Fisheries should have authorityto proceed with the introduction ofthe Bill. OIL IN the united kingdom.Payment ofRoyalties .(previous reference:Cabinet 10(22), Con-clusion 5.)4. The Cabinet had before them, a Memorandum bythe President of the Board of Trade (C4P.-36 (33))on the subject of Payment of Royalties on Oilproduced in Great Britain, circulating for theconsideration of his colleagues a Memorandum bythe Secretary for Mines regarding a difficulty which had arisen in connection with the issue of licences under the Petroleum Act, 1918, and askingauthority to issue licences to search for and produce petroleum without any stipulation aboutpayment of royalties, on the understanding that theSecretary for Mines would raise the matter againshould further discoveries of oil in substantial quantities be made, or should legislation dealingwith coal-mining royalties be undertaken.After discussion the Cabinet agreed thattheir policy should be as follows:-(a) The exploitation of oil in theUnited Kingdom must be rendered possible:(b) The payment of royalties must not be ruled out, and in this connection theCabinet were reminded that Mr. Shinwellfsdecision, issued in July 1931, did notdebar the payment of royalties butinsisted that they should be paidonly with the approval of the Secretaryfor Mines:(c) That if oil were found the Governmentwould have to consider how the royaltieswere to be settled between the owners and the exploiters:(d) That the President of the Board of trade should have authority to base any public statement he might have tomake on the subject on the above policy.
